materials are considered as promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their excellent sodium storage capacities and suitable potentials. However, the Sb-based anodes usually suffer from intense volume expansion and severe pulverization during the alloying-dealloying process, resulting in poor cycling performance. Herein, a composite anode with Sb/Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"O"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" nanoparticles embedded in N-doped porous carbon is prepared by the gas–solid dual template method. The volume change of the anode material is mitigated by the carbon layer enwrapping and the confinement of the porous structure. Nitrogen doping provides abundant sodium storage sites, thus enhancing the storage capacity of sodium ion. Furthermore, to gain the accurate kinetic interpretation of the electrochemical process, an ex-situ transmission electron microscope (TEM) characterization combined with distribution of relaxation times (DRT) is conducted. The Sb/Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"O"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"@NPC-1.0 demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance, achieving 340.3 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" at 1A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":", and maintains a capacity of 86.7 % after 1000 cycles. This work paves the way for the practical application of SIBs with high-performance and long-life Sb-based class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2024.06.080" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2024.06.080</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0030"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">A template method is employed to construct Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> embedded N-doped porous carbon.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The accuracy of kinetic analysis is improved by combining ex-situ TEM with DRT.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">N-doping creates more Na<sup>+</sup> storage sites to improve the capacity.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">The Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC anode exhibits excellent cycle performance.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0035">Sb-based materials are considered as promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their excellent sodium storage capacities and suitable potentials. However, the Sb-based anodes usually suffer from intense volume expansion and severe pulverization during the alloying-dealloying process, resulting in poor cycling performance. Herein, a composite anode with Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles embedded in N-doped porous carbon is prepared by the gas–solid dual template method. The volume change of the anode material is mitigated by the carbon layer enwrapping and the confinement of the porous structure. Nitrogen doping provides abundant sodium storage sites, thus enhancing the storage capacity of sodium ion. Furthermore, to gain the accurate kinetic interpretation of the electrochemical process, an ex-situ transmission electron microscope (TEM) characterization combined with distribution of relaxation times (DRT) is conducted. The Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance, achieving 340.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1A g<sup>−1</sup>, and maintains a capacity of 86.7&nbsp;% after 1000 cycles. This work paves the way for the practical application of SIBs with high-performance and long-life Sb-based anodes.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><strong>Step 1:</strong><span> The <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> in the bulk phase of the composites.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><strong>Step 2:</strong> Charge transfer reaction process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015"><strong>Step 3:</strong> The transport process of Na<sup>+</sup> through SEI layer.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020"><span>The accuracy of kinetic interpretation is significantly improved by combining ex-situ <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a><span> with <a href="/topics/engineering/distributions-of-relaxation-time" title="Learn more about distribution of relaxation times from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">distribution of relaxation times</a> (DRT) to </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about analyses electrochemical from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">analyses electrochemical</a> processes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0025"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0045"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (100KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (100KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724013043"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S002197972401316X"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Porous carbon</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery anode</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Cycle life</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>DRT analyses</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">The escalating demand for lithium-ion batteries, driven by the rapid proliferation of electric vehicles and various electronic devices, is being hampered by the limited availability of lithium resources. Therefore, there is a pressing need to explore alternatives capable of replacing lithium-ion batteries on a large scale to meet the surging energy storage requirements <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) emerge as promising candidates due to their abundant reserves, cost-effectiveness, and similar electrochemical behavior to lithium-ion batteries <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a><span>. However, a critical challenge arises in SIBs from the incompatibility of graphite anodes, commonly employed in commercial lithium-ion batteries. The <a href="/topics/engineering/ionic-radius" title="Learn more about ionic radius from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic radius</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> is approximately 55&nbsp;% larger than that of Li<sup>+</sup>, rendering the existing graphite anodes unsuitable for SIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a><span>. Consequently, the ongoing research is directed towards developing high-performance SIB <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a><span> to expedite their practical implementation in <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-application" title="Learn more about energy storage applications from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage applications</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>In terms of anodes, there is a growing interest in developing high-performance <a href="/topics/engineering/anode-alloy" title="Learn more about alloy anodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">alloy anodes</a> for SIBs due to the ability of metals to engage in multi-electron alloying reactions with Na</span><sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a><span>. Among the various anode materials, <a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony</a> (Sb)-based compounds have garnered significant attention due to their impressive theoretical capacity (Na</span><sub>3</sub>Sb: 660 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>) and suitable Na-reaction potentials (∼0.5&nbsp;V vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>. Unfortunately, Sb-based anodes usually exhibit sluggish kinetic processes and substantial volume changes (up to 290&nbsp;%) during the alloying and dealloying reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a><span>. Nano-engineering of active materials, <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/interfacial-engineering" title="Learn more about interfacial engineering from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interfacial engineering</a>, and the formation of composites with carbon materials represent widely adopted strategies in contemporary research </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a><span>. Among these, carbon-coated active materials play a <a href="/topics/engineering/pivotal-role" title="Learn more about pivotal role from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pivotal role</a> in mitigating volume variations and enhancing electrode conductivity. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a><span>. Additionally, the construction of a <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a><span> matrix facilitates the establishment of efficient electron and ion pathways between the active material and the electrolyte, thereby promoting <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> efficiency </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the inherent porosity of such structures provides buffer space to accommodate volume changes during alloying reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. Consequently, the deliberate synthesis of homogeneous porous composites by integrating Sb with a porous carbon matrix emerges as an effective approach for fabricating anodes tailored for SIBs. Yang et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span> prepared a hybrid anode of <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> Sb/N doped layered porous carbon through a simple bottom-up approach, which exhibited excellent cycling performance (280.5 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> up to 500 cycles). Xu et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a><span> used the spraying method and partial reduction process to synthesize Sb-based <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a><span> immersed in N-doped carbon microcavities, demonstrating an extraordinary <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage capacity retention of 245.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> after 10,000 cycles at 10 A g<sup>−1</sup><span>. Despite the substantial research efforts, the underlying reaction mechanism and electrochemical behavior during cycling in SIBs remain insufficiently understood. To expedite the commercialization of SIBs, it is essential to conduct in-depth investigations into the electrochemical reaction processes of anode materials. By elucidating these mechanisms, we can pave the way for more efficient and reliable <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-solution" title="Learn more about energy storage solutions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage solutions</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">In this study, we synthesized Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> embedded in N-doped porous </span><a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-composite" title="Learn more about carbon composites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon composites</a><span> though a gas–solid dual <a href="/topics/engineering/template-method" title="Learn more about template method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">template method</a><span>. This specific structure plays a crucial role in enhancing <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> and reducing ionic diffusion pathways. Additionally, it effectively mitigates the volume change experienced by Sb/Sb</span></span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> under repeated cycling. Meanwhile, the introduction of N atoms into the composites provides abundant active sites for Na</span><sup>+</sup> storage, thereby improving the overall sodium storage performance. Furthermore, achieving accurate time-scale modeling of the cells is essential for kinetic interpretation. However, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) responses can be coupled, posing challenges in constructing equivalent circuits <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span><span>. To address this, we propose a novel approach by combining ex-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM) with the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) to analyze </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-process" title="Learn more about electrochemical processes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical processes</a>. This synergistic approach significantly enhances the accuracy of kinetic interpretation. Considering these advantages, the prepared composites exhibit enormous potential as high-performance anodes for SIBs in practical applications.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span><span>Firstly, 3&nbsp;g <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span> citrate, 5&nbsp;g <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/melamine" title="Learn more about melamine from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">melamine</a>, an appropriate amount of ethanol and different masses (0.5&nbsp;g, 1.0&nbsp;g or 1.5&nbsp;g) </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony</a><span> trichloride are mixed in the mortar. Then, we continuously grind until all the ethanol has evaporated, leaving a solid mixture. The solid mixed powder is calcined in a tube furnace at 700&nbsp;°C for 2&nbsp;h with a <a href="/topics/engineering/ramp-rate" title="Learn more about ramp rate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ramp rate</a> of 2.5&nbsp;°C min</span></span><sup>−1</sup><span> under the protection of <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a>. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the samples are washed with 80&nbsp;mL distilled water for 30&nbsp;min at a stirring speed of 300&nbsp;rpm. Subsequently, the samples are dried in a vacuum oven at 100&nbsp;°C for 8&nbsp;h. These as-obtained products are labelled as Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5, respectively. For comparison, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@C-1.0 is prepared though the same method but without melamine.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> measurements are carried out at ordinary temperature, and the signals are recorded by a Xplora plus Raman (Horiba Scientific) using a 532&nbsp;nm <a href="/topics/engineering/laser-excitation" title="Learn more about laser excitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">laser excitation</a><span><span>. The <a href="/topics/engineering/microscopic-morphology" title="Learn more about microscopic morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microscopic morphology</a> of the as-prepared samples is observed by </span><a href="/topics/engineering/scanning-electron-microscope" title="Learn more about scanning electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">scanning electron microscope</a> (SEM, Hitachi SU3500) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G2 F20) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). N</span></span></span><sub>2</sub><span> adsorption desorption isotherms are obtained by using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at 77&nbsp;K (ASAP 2020 instrument) to analyze the pore size and specific surface area (SSA). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher K-Alpha American with an Al Kα X-ray source) is used to investigate the surface chemical state and <a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental composition</a> of samples. The structure features and crystal phases of samples are carried out through X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANPCE, Germany).</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The anode is fabricated by mixing Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC, conductive carbon black and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> difluoride in an 80:10:10&nbsp;wt ratios with N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurries are spread on the <a href="/topics/engineering/copper-foil" title="Learn more about copper foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">copper foil</a> and dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 80&nbsp;°C to obtain the working electrode. The mass loading of working electrode is about 1.5&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>−2</sup>. The electrolytes are composed of NaPF<sub>6</sub><span> (1&nbsp;M) that dissolved in a mixture of DMC and EC (volume ratio: 1:1) with 5&nbsp;% FEC. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> is evaluated by assembling the half-cells in a glove box (H</span><sub>2</sub>O, O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.01&nbsp;ppm) using CR2032 coin cells with Na metal foil as a counter electrode. Using a CHI760E electrochemical workstation, CV curves are collected at different scan rates with a voltage window of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V. The CV curves are collected at dissimilar scan rates with a voltage window of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V by a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. EIS characterization is investigated in the frequency range of 100&nbsp;kHz–0.01&nbsp;Hz. The validity of the EIS measurements is tested by means of Kramer-Kronig analyses with the aid of ec-idea software. The DRT data is obtained by using calculate from the impedance data with open-source MATLAB script-based software (DRT Tools).</div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> illustrates the concise construction of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles embedded in an N-doped carbon skeleton using a multiscale structural engineering strategy. In the typical preparation process, antimony trichloride is utilized as Sb sources for the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@NPC, while <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span> citrate and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/melamine" title="Learn more about melamine from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">melamine</a> are used as carbon and nitrogen sources. Subsequently, the solid powder is subjected to a one-step </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> and partial reduction process, followed by calcining, resulting in the formation of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles embedded in the N-doped porous carbon skeleton. Finally, through removing the spontaneously formed K<sub>2</sub>O templates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>) with distilled water to obtain the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a–f reveals the SEM images of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5, respectively. The unique 3D structure of the samples provides an efficient transmission path for electrons and Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. To further reveal the microstructure of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC, we utilize the TEM to analyze the relevant samples. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a–c demonstrate that the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles are embedded within the porous carbon skeleton structure. Different addition amounts of antimony trichloride impact the loading and dispersion degrees of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. As demonstrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d–f, it can be concluded that excessive Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> nanoparticles will aggregate into large particles within the carbon skeleton after high-temperature <a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a>. Large particles generally cause significant mechanical stress and even severe volume expansion on electrode materials </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g–i further reveal the presence of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles cladded by porous carbon. The lattice fringes have an interplanar spacing of 0.321&nbsp;nm corresponding to the (2&nbsp;2&nbsp;2) crystal planes of Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, and 0.311&nbsp;nm corresponding to the (0&nbsp;1&nbsp;2) crystal planes of Sb <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a><span>. The element mapping results demonstrate that the sample contains Sb, C, O and N elements, which are homogeneously distributed in the composites. Moreover, the overlapping signals of N and C elements indicate that the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nitrogen-atom" title="Learn more about nitrogen atoms from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nitrogen atoms</a> have been evenly doped into the carbon skeleton.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1.jpg" height="349" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (267KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (267KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Synthesis process of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2.jpg" height="368" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (502KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (502KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Morphology characterizations of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> images of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (a, d), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (b, e), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (c, f).</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3.jpg" height="877" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Morphology characterizations of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (a, d), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (b, e), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 (c, f). Lattice fringes (g–i), and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> results (j) of the Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 composites.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a shows that the crystal structures of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 are analyzed by <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a>. The results demonstrate that all the peaks of each sample correspond to Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (JCPDS No. 05-0534) and Sb (JCPDS No. 35-0732) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a><span>. The surface area of the samples is further examined by measuring the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. All samples exhibited type IV isotherms with <a href="/topics/engineering/hysteresis-loop" title="Learn more about hysteresis loops from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hysteresis loops</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b). Meanwhile, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 exhibit similar adsorption properties at extremely-low relative pressures. It can be determined that <a href="/topics/engineering/micropore" title="Learn more about micropores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">micropores</a> coexist in the samples. According to the BET analysis, the surface areas of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are calculated to be 303.8, 379.6 and 232.2&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c shows that the pore sizes of these three samples range from 1&nbsp;nm to 40&nbsp;nm. There is almost no microporous structure in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@PC-1.0, which due to melamine is not added during the synthesis process. Therefore, it can be concluded that the formation of micropores is related to the gas template generated during the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a> process, while </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> originate more from the K</span><sub>2</sub>O solid template. The Raman spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d displays the typical peaks at 1350 and 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, which are attribute to the D-band (disordered structure) and G-band (sp<sup>2</sup><span> carbon structure). The increase in the intensity of the D peak can be attributed to the successful doping of nitrogen and the creation of lattice defects, which lead to the disorder of the <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a><span>. Generally, <a href="/topics/engineering/structural-defect" title="Learn more about structural defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural defects</a> in carbon materials can be revealed by the intensity ratio </span></span><em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em>. Obviously, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 displays a higher <em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em> ratio of 1.16 than those of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (1.06), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (0.92) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@C-1.0 (0.77). Abundant <a href="/topics/engineering/defect-structure" title="Learn more about defect structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect structures</a> are beneficial for </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> storage </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. In addition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to analyze the chemical composition of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. The elemental mapping results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e) are confirmed by the presence of C, Sb, O and N elements in the full spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>f, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/deconvolution" title="Learn more about deconvolution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deconvolution</a> of the high-resolution C 1s spectrum indicates four subpeaks, which correspond to C</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C (284.8&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">O (285.5&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (286.5&nbsp;eV) and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O (288.4&nbsp;eV) bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. The Sb 3d XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g) of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 shows six characteristic peaks: metallic Sb at 530.1&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>5/2</sub>) and 539.6&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>3/2</sub>), Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> at 530.9&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>5/2</sub>) and 540.4&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>3/2</sub>), and O (1s) at 532.3&nbsp;eV and 533.5&nbsp;eV <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>h indicates the N 1s high-resolution XPS spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. Obviously, the spectrum exhibits three peaks at approximately 398.4&nbsp;eV, 400.3&nbsp;eV and 402.9&nbsp;eV, corresponding to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and graphitic N, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i, pyridinic N has lone pairs occupying sp<sup>2</sup><span> orbitals, while pyrrolic N has p-orbital lone pairs predominantly located at edges or <a href="/topics/engineering/defect-site" title="Learn more about defect sites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect sites</a> in the carbon skeleton plane. Both pyridinic N and pyrrolic N facilitate Na</span><sup>+</sup> absorption, contributing to an increase in surface capacitance capacity. Regrettably, graphitic N is unreactive in absorbing Na<sup>+</sup> due to the two unpaired electrons in its two p-orbitals. Based on <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S2 and S3</span></span></a>, it can be found that Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 also exhibit similar <a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental compositions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental compositions</a> and properties, which demonstrate the generalizability of this synthesize method. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>, the percentages of pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphite N in these samples are calculated based on N1s high-resolution XPS spectrum.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4.jpg" height="606" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (756KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (756KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites. (b) Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm. (c) pore-size distributions of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (d) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (e) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0, (f) C 1s, (g) Sb 3d and (h) N 1s spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. (i) Schematic structure of the binding conditions of N in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">The performance of Na<sup>+</sup> storage in the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites is evaluated by assembling 2032 type coin cells. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a exhibits the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. During the first discharge process, a peak at 0.94&nbsp;V is observed due to the formation of SEI films and the generation of irreversible terms. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. The two cathodic peaks located at 0.43 and 0.51&nbsp;V are ascribed to the alloying processes of Sb to Na<sub>3</sub>Sb. The two anodic peaks located at 0.75&nbsp;V and 0.84&nbsp;V are corresponding to the process of dealloying <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>. Interestingly, the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 also show the same alloying/dealloying process (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b exhibits a detailed description of the alloying reaction mechanism during the CV process of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. The reaction process can be summarized by the following equation: Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;6Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;6e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;2Sb&nbsp;+&nbsp;3Na<sub>2</sub>O, Sb&nbsp;+&nbsp;xNa<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;xe<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;⇋&nbsp;Na<sub>x</sub>Sb (0&nbsp;≤&nbsp;x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;3). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c–e exhibits the galvanostatic current discharge/charge curves of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 at a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The initial reversible capacity and coulombic efficiency of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 are 969.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 55&nbsp;% for SIBs. The initial coulombic efficiency for Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are 46&nbsp;% and 52&nbsp;%, respectively. The loss of first-loop capacity is generally caused by the formation of SEI films on the surface of porous carbon materials and the irreversible phase formation.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5.jpg" height="780" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (856KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (856KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 0.1 mVs<sup>−1</sup>. (b) Mechanism diagram of alloying reaction in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites. (c–e) Charge/discharge curves at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup> of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (f) <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites in their initial cycle. (g) In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> spectrum of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 2th cycle. (h) Rate performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at different current densities (i) cycling performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">Detailed reaction kinetics of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC in SIBs is explored using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) range from 100&nbsp;kHz to 0.01&nbsp;Hz. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>f exhibits the typical <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> for the anode of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC, which consisting of semicircles and diagonal lines. The semicircle represents the <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a>, while the diagonal line is related to the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>. The EIS equivalent circuit diagrams of fresh half cells is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>. Where R<sub>e</sub> is the ohmic impedance, R<sub>ct</sub> is the charge transfer impedance, Z<sub>w</sub> is the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion impedance and R<sub>SEI</sub> is the impedance of Na<sup>+</sup><span> across the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a>. The large surface area offers sufficient electrode/electrolyte interface for Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> uptake and facilitates fast charge transfer reactions. The <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/hierarchical-porous" title="Learn more about hierarchical porous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hierarchical porous</a> structure provides a fast transfer pathway and reduces the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> transfer distance, while the crosslinked carbon network provides a continuous path for <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a><span>. In addition, N-doping improves the electrochemical responsiveness and <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> of the Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g shows the in-situ impedance spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0. After two cycles, the smooth impedance variation and excellent recovery are attributed to the stability of the porous <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a>. Afterwards, the rate performances of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC are explored at different current densities. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h, it can be found that the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 achieves high charge capacities of 503.6, 430.4, 384.9, 340.3, 297.7 and 186.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. After continuous inrush of high current (5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>), the reversible capacity can be restored to 477.4&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> when the current density is back to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The high-rate capability of the material can be attributed to the integrated N-doped porous network structure embedded with Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles. To explore the stability of the N-doped porous network structure, the long cycling performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are investigated at the current density of 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>i). After 1000 cycles, the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 remains a high capacity of 300.3&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 86.7&nbsp;%, which is superior to Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (219.5&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 77.8&nbsp;%) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (159.4&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 51.8&nbsp;%). To evaluate the practicality of our electrodes, we select the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 electrode with <a href="/topics/engineering/optimal-performance" title="Learn more about optimal performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">optimal performance</a> to assemble the full cell. The cathode electrode of the full cell is Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) electrode. The full cell delivers the initial charge/discharge capacities of 123.8/107.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C with a high ICE of 87.1&nbsp;% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>), and the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves show agreeable overlaps after the first cycle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>). The charge capacity of 98.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C can be obtained after 100 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 86.8&nbsp;%, demonstrating excellent cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080"><span>During the cycling process, the formation of SEI films not only affects the electron transfer resistance of the <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a>, but is also related to the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> transfer resistance. Therefore, to further investigate the evolution law of SEI films in the sodium <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a>, it is necessary to analyze the effect of SEI films generation on the electron transfer and Na</span><sup>+</sup> transport at the electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a shows that the processes that Na<sup>+</sup> undergoes in the composite include diffusion in the bulk phase, charge transfer reactions and transport processes across the SEI films. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b, the SEI film thickens gradually with the charge–discharge reaction. The corresponding Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-path" title="Learn more about diffusion path from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion path</a> is decreased in the bulk phase and the path across the SEI films is increased. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>c demonstrates the thickness of the SEI films after 2nd, 5th, 100th, 500th and 1000th cycles through <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM analysis</a>, which profoundly reveals the variation pattern of SEI films thickness.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6.jpg" height="758" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (764KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (764KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0065"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>(a) Schematic diagram of <a href="/topics/engineering/distributions-of-relaxation-time" title="Learn more about DRT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT</a> testing and its processes related to τ</span><sub>1</sub>, τ<sub>2</sub>, and τ<sub>3</sub>. (b) Schematic diagram of Na<sup>+</sup><span> pathway changes before and after <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> cycling.
