(c) TEM images (Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0) of SEI film thickness with different number of cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>a reveals the trend of impedance change at different number of cycles. As the number of cycles increases, the ohmic impedance does not change significantly. Due to electrode activation, the charge transfer impedance decreases first and then increases. The diffusion impedance decreases lead to an appropriate increase in the ion diffusion rate. Overall, the impedance shows an increasing trend. However, the impedance spectrum is difficult to distinguish the influence of the individual frequency components. Therefore, it is important to realize a detailed analysis of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/phase-interface" title="Learn more about phase interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phase interface</a> evolution process during Na</span><sup>+</sup> storage. Various kinetic processes with specific relaxation features can be clearly identified in time scales through DRT analysis <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0315" name="bb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. Extracting and analyzing time-scale information in cells will provide insights into the investigation of kinetic aspects such as Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> diffusion charge transfer, and interfacial evolution. In the <a href="/topics/engineering/relaxation-time-spectrum" title="Learn more about DRT spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT spectrum</a>, the x-axis is a time constant, representing the inherent characteristics of each </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-process" title="Learn more about electrochemical process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical process</a><span>, and the peak intensity is the impedance of the corresponding process. Therefore, various processes with different <a href="/topics/engineering/response-time" title="Learn more about response times from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">response times</a> can be separated and identified in the DRT spectrum, and the changes of each process can be tracked. In general, the response times corresponding to diffusion of Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> in the electrode material bulk phase, the charge transfer reaction and the transport of Na<sup>+</sup> across the SEI films are τ<sub>1</sub>&nbsp;&gt;&nbsp;10&nbsp;s, 0.01&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;τ<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;10&nbsp;s and 0.001&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;τ<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.01&nbsp;s, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0320" name="bb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a><span>. In this study, DRT analysis is performed on EISs with different number of cycles to distinguish the corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> processes at the characteristic frequencies. The selected EIS data is first validated at Kramers-Kronig to fulfill the requirements of DRT impedance analysis. As illustrated in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b–c, in the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0, the intensity of the τ<sub>1</sub> characteristic peaks gradually decrease as the number of cycles increases, which improves the wetting degree of the electrolyte to the electrode and the diffusion process becomes favorable. The τ<sub>2</sub><span> characteristic peaks show a significant decrease during the <a href="/topics/engineering/activation-process" title="Learn more about activation process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation process</a> and tend to flatten after activation. The intensity of the τ</span><sub>3</sub> characteristic peak initially decreases, and after the activation process, the peak intensity gradually increases and shifts to the right, indicating that the transport resistance of Na<sup>+</sup> in the SEI films increase gradually. Fig. d–f show the variation trend of τ<sub>1</sub>, τ<sub>2</sub> and τ<sub>3</sub> in detail, and more clearly reveal the basis of the electrochemical reaction process. The above results demonstrate the continuous generation of SEI films during the cycling process, which is consistent with the TEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c). Meanwhile, it reveals the changing rule between the phase boundaries inside the electrode during Na<sup>+</sup> storage process. The evolution of the electrochemical reactions during cycling is further tested through CV tests at the scan rate of 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, and the corresponding CV curves of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 electrodes at 2 and 1000 cycles are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>g-i. The reduction peak and <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a><span> peak undergo a process of increase first and then decrease, which is consistent with the trend of EIS and DRT. The positions of all peaks remain almost constant, reflecting the stability of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/materials-structure" title="Learn more about material structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material structure</a>. The Sb/Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 also exhibit similar patterns of tendency in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S8 and S9</span></span></a>. Meanwhile, to further verify the changes inside the cell, the structure of the working electrodes before and after 1000 cycles of inspection are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>a–f. The Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 electrodes exhibit volume expansions of 31.1&nbsp;%, 32.7&nbsp;% and 40.3&nbsp;%, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>a–c illustrate that Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 exhibit fewer cracks on the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-surface" title="Learn more about electrode surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode surface</a> after cycling, while Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 shows an increased number of cracks. It is shown that the porous carbon structure synthesized by this method possess excellent stability and is suitable to be used as <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> for Na</span><sup>+</sup> batteries.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7.jpg" height="625" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (657KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (657KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0070"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><span>(a–c) <a href="/topics/engineering/distributions-of-relaxation-time" title="Learn more about DRT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT</a> analysis results obtained from </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 composites. (d–f) τ1, τ2, and τ3 peak intensity variation trend. (g-i) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 1.0 mVs<sup>-1</sup>at different cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">To further reveal the excellent Na<sup>+</sup> storage kinetics and mechanism of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 electrodes, the CV measurements are performed at several scan rates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a–c). It is evident that as the scan rate increases, the existing depolarization peak expands to a higher potential range, indicating the dominance of capacitively behaving Na<sup>+</sup> storage processes. As we all know, there is a relationship between the measured peak current (<em>i</em>) and the scan rate (<em>v</em>) that follows the equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0005" name="be0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="e0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mtext></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.405ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3188.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mtext is="true">b</mtext></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mtext is="true">b</mtext></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where a and b are adjustable constants. When b is close to 0.5, indicating that the electrochemical reaction is controlled by diffusion process, while b approaches 1.0, representing the electrochemical reaction is surface capacitive-dominated. The b-value can be calculated by linearly fitting the log(<em>i</em>)–log(<em>v</em>) points. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>d–f, the b-values of two redox peaks for Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (calculated to be 0.75 and 0.77), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (calculated to be 0.80 and 0.83) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (calculated to be 0.74 and 0.76) demonstrate that three electrode capacities are from the capacitive process. Furthermore, the Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanism can be further verified by probing the current response to the applied scan rate, which can be described as equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mtext><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mtext><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="19.582ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 8431.2 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(512,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(875,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2054,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3110,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4093,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4800,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5801,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6783,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">v</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">v</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>in which k<sub>1</sub> and k<sub>2</sub> are constants, k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> represents the surface-driven pseudocapacitive contribution and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup> represents the ion diffusion-controlled process. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>g–i indicates the capacitive-controlled contribution ratios of the three electrodes at the scan rate of 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S8–S10</span></span></a> show the values of other scan rates). Calculated by integral fitting, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 exhibits a capacitive-controlled contribution of 73.9&nbsp;%, which is higher than those of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (65.3&nbsp;%) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (64.7&nbsp;%). The ratio of pseudocapacitive contribution increases with the scan rate (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>j–l), indicating that the storage capacity of Na<sup>+</sup> is dominated by a capacitive process. Therefore, it can be inferred that the high percentage of capacitance contribution is the reason for the superior rate capability of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8.jpg" height="833" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (886KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (886KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0075"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (a–c) CV curves of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at different scan rates. (d–f) log <em>i</em> versus log <em>v</em> plots at two redox peaks of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (g–i) The capacitive contribution to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about Sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium</a> storage at 1&nbsp;mV·s</span><sup>−1</sup>. (j–l) Contribution ratios of capacitance and diffusion at different scan rates for the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">In summary, we prepared composite materials of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span> nanoparticles embedded in N-doped porous carbon using the gas–solid dual <a href="/topics/engineering/template-method" title="Learn more about template method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">template method</a><span>. Carbon encapsulation and the <a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structure</a> not only significantly limits the volume expansion during the alloying process, but also controls the diffusion of </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> during cycling, thereby improving the kinetics of alloying reactions. The synergistic combination of ex-situ TEM and DRT analysis significantly enhances the accuracy of kinetic interpretation in SIBs. This novel method proposes an effective approach to mitigate volume expansion in Sb-based electrodes. The Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 demonstrates excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a>, achieving 340.3 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 1A g<sup>−1</sup> and maintaining 86.7&nbsp;% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. These findings provide a promising strategy for the practical application of SIBs, particularly in the development of high-performance and long-lasting anode materials.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><strong>Guang Ma:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Investigation. <strong>Chong Xu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision. <strong>Dongyuan Zhang:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Sai Che:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Ye Wang:</strong> Supervision, Investigation. <strong>Jiahao Yang:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. <strong>Kaiyi Chen:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Validation. <strong>Yang Sun:</strong> Supervision, Investigation. <strong>Shuang Liu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Junjie Fu:</strong> Validation, Investigation. <strong>Zizheng Zhou:</strong> Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Yiming Qu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Changsheng Ding:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft. <strong>Yongfeng Li:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">We gratefully acknowledge the financial support from the <span id="gp010">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (Nos. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22238012</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22178384</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22108301</span></span></a>), and the <span id="gp005">Science Foundation of China University of Petroleum, Beijing</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">ZX20230242</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. href="/science/article/pii/S254243512200232X/pdfft?md5=dfe89139c1a017908354942a8ee2e148&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S254243512200232X-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0310"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448 1.228-1.462.008-1.06-.316-1.45-1.23-1.45h-.347m-.977-.94h1.03c1.68 0 2.523.586 2.534 2.39.01 1.688-.607 2.4-2.534 Mitra</div><div id="ref-id-h0315" class="title text-m">Design of low-stress robust silicon and silicon-carbide anode with high areal capacity and high energy density for next-generation lithium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Chem. Soni, J.B. Robinson, P.R. Shearing, D.J.L. Brett, A.J.E. Rettie, T.S. Miller</div><div id="ref-id-h0320" class="title text-m">Lithium-sulfur battery diagnostics through distribution of relaxation times analysis</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Energy Storage Mater., 51 (2022), pp. 97-107</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor pdf link anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829722003245/pdfft?md5=e66137c5813bd41eba5ff112c4a882f6&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S2405829722003245-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0320"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85132896006&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0320"><span href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Lithium-sulfur%20battery%20diagnostics%20through%20distribution%20of%20relaxation%20times%20analysis&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=R.%20Soni&amp;author=J.B.%20Robinson&amp;author=P.R.%20Shearing&amp;author=D.J.L.%20Brett&amp;author=A.J.E.%20Rettie&amp;author=T.S.%20Miller" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (9)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1572665724008671"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">One-step synthesis of Sb/SnO&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;@C hybrid nanocomposites as high-performance anode materials for lithium/sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Antimony (Sb)-based materials have shown great promise as anode for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) owing to their elevated theoretical capacity and favorable operating voltage. Nevertheless, a significant challenge limiting their practical application is the considerable volume change experienced during charge and discharge cycles. Herein, Sb/SnO<sub>2</sub>@C hybrid nanocomposites were synthesized utilizing glucose as a carbon source through a one-step hydrothermal self-assembly method. The coexistence of Sb and SnO<sub>2</sub> phases within the carbon layer will mutually buffer due to their different reaction potentials, effectively alleviating volume expansion. Meanwhile, the highly disordered and amorphous carbon component of the composite has numerous defects, which provide abundant active sites and further mitigate the volume expansion effects to some degree. As a result, the Sb/SnO<sub>2</sub>@C composite, when utilized as an anode in LIBs, exhibits a reversible capacity of 302.6&nbsp;mAh/g after 100 cycles at 100&nbsp;mA/g and demonstrates remarkable long-term cycle stability, maintaining a capacity of 208.6&nbsp;mAh/g at 1000&nbsp;mA/g after 3000 cycles. When applied in SIBs, it achieves a reversible specific capacity of 305.8&nbsp;mAh/g following 100 cycles at a current density of 100&nbsp;mA/g and maintains a capacity of 115.3&nbsp;mAh/g following 2000 cycles at 1000&nbsp;mA/g. This study offers significant insights into the advancement of alloy-type anode materials for rechargeable batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24045997"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Constructing CoS&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;/FeS&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; heterostructures on hollow carbon spheres with promoted reaction kinetics for high-rate and stable sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Energy Storage</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0045">Pyrite (FeS<sub>2</sub>) has been regarded as one perspective candidate of anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its substantial theoretical capacity. However, FeS<sub>2</sub> still faces with inferior rate and cycling performances mainly caused by its low electrical conductivity, sluggish Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics and vigorous volume fluctuations during cycling. Herein, we have developed a simple spray drying and subsequent carbonization/sulfurization combined strategy to synthesize a series of heterogeneous CoS<sub>2</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub> particles anchored on hollow carbon spheres (CoS<sub>2</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub>/C) as anodes for SIBs. Through the rational heterostructure engineering of external CoS<sub>2</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub> with interior hollow carbon structure creation, the delicately designed CoS<sub>2</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub>/C hybrid composite affords promoted reaction kinetics with accelerated electron/ion transport at the heterointerfaces, as well as strengthened structural integrity by accommodating the volume fluctuations upon cycling. As a result, the optimal CoS<sub>2</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub>/C-1 hybrid composite exhibits high reversible capacity of 696&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, superior rate capability of 513&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>−1</sup>, and outstanding cycling stability with 96.5&nbsp;% capacity retention over 1300&nbsp;cycles at 2 A g<sup>−1</sup>. It is expected that this work might provide valuable insights for designing and developing heterostructured transition metal sulfide-based anode materials, aiming at enhancing their rate and cycling properties for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838824034248"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Interface engineering-induced enhancements in sodium-ion batteries: A nexus of ZnS nanoparticles and reduced graphene oxide for augmented storage and conductivity</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Alloys and Compounds</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0055">Due to the inherent sluggish kinetics and the pronounced volumetric expansion of zinc sulfide (ZnS), it has become a prevalent modification strategy to regulate its morphology and composite with graphene for using ZnS as anodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nevertheless, the elucidation of mechanisms underpinning the electrochemical performance facilitated by graphene incorporation remains scant. To further describe the synergistic mechanism, the ultrafine ZnS nanoparticles anchored on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) were synthesized through a simple solvothermal method. Research shows that the ZSG (ZnS nanoparticles-reduced graphene oxide composite) electrode suggests superior rate capability, maintaining a reversible specific capacity of 228.6 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> upon returning from a high current density of 5 A·g<sup>−1</sup>. Furthermore, the nanoscale integration of ZnS particles with rGO synergistically mitigates the structural expansion of the ZSG electrode encountered during cycling, thereby decelerating the degradation of cyclic performance. Insights gleaned from first-principles calculations and comprehensive electrochemical evaluations reveal that the built-in electric field, engendered within the composite architecture, substantially augments charge transfer ability and mitigates the energy barriers impeding sodium ion (Na<sup>+</sup>) diffusion accordingly. Consequently, the methodology adopted for synthesis and the synergistic modification mechanism can proffer a reference for the design of advanced anode materials in SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24032687"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">N/P/O co-doped porous carbon derived from agroindustry waste of peanut shell for sodium-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Therefore, it is very urgent to develop new anode materials with satisfied sodium storage capacity for the large-scale application of SIBs. Currently, three kinds of anode materials for SIBs have been widely studied and reported, including: (i) carbonaceous materials (soft carbon, graphene, hard carbon) mainly via intercalation mechanisms [15–18]; (ii) main group metal (such as Sn, Sb, Bi) utilising alloy-conversion mechanisms [19–21]; (iii) metallides (sulphides, selenide, nitrides) based on conversion reaction mechanisms [22–25]. Among these materials, carbon-based materials are of very interest for their stable structure, low environmental pollution, low cost, excellent electrical conductivity, and high sodium storage capacity [26].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0040">Porous bio‑carbon from agroindustry waste behaves one of the most promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) because of its high sodium storage capacity, low cost, sustainability, and low charge/discharge voltage platform. Herein, we have developed a new N/P/O co-doped porous hard carbon derived from peanut shell (PSCNP) synthesized via KOH activation, hydrothermal doping combined with carbonization method, using chitosan as nitrogen source, phytic acid as phosphorus source, and peanut shell as carbon and oxygen source. Through seriously regulating the calcination temperature, the optimal PSCNP-800 carbonization at 800&nbsp;°C can well combine the advantages of the natural rich porous microstructure of peanut shells, large graphite interlayer spacing (0.379&nbsp;nm), and short diffusion distance for sodium-ion. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the PSCNP-800 delivered a reversible capacity of 248.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100&nbsp;cycles at 25&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. This work could provide a possible idea for the preparation of N/P/O co-doped porous hard carbon from low-cost agroindustry waste as anodes for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adfm.202415680" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Electrolyte Chemistry Toward Sulfur-Rich Interphase for Wide-Temperature Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Advanced Functional Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.3390/en17225768" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Beyond Lithium: Future Battery Technologies for Sustainable Energy Storage</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
