Xu et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a><span> used the spraying method and partial reduction process to synthesize Sb-based <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a><span> immersed in N-doped carbon microcavities, demonstrating an extraordinary <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage capacity retention of 245.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> after 10,000 cycles at 10 A g<sup>−1</sup><span>. Despite the substantial research efforts, the underlying reaction mechanism and electrochemical behavior during cycling in SIBs remain insufficiently understood. To expedite the commercialization of SIBs, it is essential to conduct in-depth investigations into the electrochemical reaction processes of anode materials. By elucidating these mechanisms, we can pave the way for more efficient and reliable <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-solution" title="Learn more about energy storage solutions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage solutions</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">In this study, we synthesized Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> embedded in N-doped porous </span><a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-composite" title="Learn more about carbon composites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon composites</a><span> though a gas–solid dual <a href="/topics/engineering/template-method" title="Learn more about template method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">template method</a><span>. This specific structure plays a crucial role in enhancing <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> and reducing ionic diffusion pathways. Additionally, it effectively mitigates the volume change experienced by Sb/Sb</span></span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> under repeated cycling. Meanwhile, the introduction of N atoms into the composites provides abundant active sites for Na</span><sup>+</sup> storage, thereby improving the overall sodium storage performance. Furthermore, achieving accurate time-scale modeling of the cells is essential for kinetic interpretation. However, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) responses can be coupled, posing challenges in constructing equivalent circuits <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span><span>. To address this, we propose a novel approach by combining ex-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM) with the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) to analyze </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-process" title="Learn more about electrochemical processes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical processes</a>. This synergistic approach significantly enhances the accuracy of kinetic interpretation. Considering these advantages, the prepared composites exhibit enormous potential as high-performance anodes for SIBs in practical applications.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span><span>Firstly, 3&nbsp;g <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span> citrate, 5&nbsp;g <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/melamine" title="Learn more about melamine from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">melamine</a>, an appropriate amount of ethanol and different masses (0.5&nbsp;g, 1.0&nbsp;g or 1.5&nbsp;g) </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony</a><span> trichloride are mixed in the mortar. Then, we continuously grind until all the ethanol has evaporated, leaving a solid mixture. The solid mixed powder is calcined in a tube furnace at 700&nbsp;°C for 2&nbsp;h with a <a href="/topics/engineering/ramp-rate" title="Learn more about ramp rate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ramp rate</a> of 2.5&nbsp;°C min</span></span><sup>−1</sup><span> under the protection of <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a>. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the samples are washed with 80&nbsp;mL distilled water for 30&nbsp;min at a stirring speed of 300&nbsp;rpm. Subsequently, the samples are dried in a vacuum oven at 100&nbsp;°C for 8&nbsp;h. These as-obtained products are labelled as Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5, respectively. For comparison, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@C-1.0 is prepared though the same method but without melamine.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> measurements are carried out at ordinary temperature, and the signals are recorded by a Xplora plus Raman (Horiba Scientific) using a 532&nbsp;nm <a href="/topics/engineering/laser-excitation" title="Learn more about laser excitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">laser excitation</a><span><span>. The <a href="/topics/engineering/microscopic-morphology" title="Learn more about microscopic morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microscopic morphology</a> of the as-prepared samples is observed by </span><a href="/topics/engineering/scanning-electron-microscope" title="Learn more about scanning electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">scanning electron microscope</a> (SEM, Hitachi SU3500) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G2 F20) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). N</span></span></span><sub>2</sub><span> adsorption desorption isotherms are obtained by using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at 77&nbsp;K (ASAP 2020 instrument) to analyze the pore size and specific surface area (SSA). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher K-Alpha American with an Al Kα X-ray source) is used to investigate the surface chemical state and <a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental composition</a> of samples. The structure features and crystal phases of samples are carried out through X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANPCE, Germany).</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The anode is fabricated by mixing Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC, conductive carbon black and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> difluoride in an 80:10:10&nbsp;wt ratios with N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurries are spread on the <a href="/topics/engineering/copper-foil" title="Learn more about copper foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">copper foil</a> and dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 80&nbsp;°C to obtain the working electrode. The mass loading of working electrode is about 1.5&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>−2</sup>. The electrolytes are composed of NaPF<sub>6</sub><span> (1&nbsp;M) that dissolved in a mixture of DMC and EC (volume ratio: 1:1) with 5&nbsp;% FEC. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> is evaluated by assembling the half-cells in a glove box (H</span><sub>2</sub>O, O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.01&nbsp;ppm) using CR2032 coin cells with Na metal foil as a counter electrode. Using a CHI760E electrochemical workstation, CV curves are collected at different scan rates with a voltage window of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V. The CV curves are collected at dissimilar scan rates with a voltage window of 0.01–3.0&nbsp;V by a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. EIS characterization is investigated in the frequency range of 100&nbsp;kHz–0.01&nbsp;Hz. The validity of the EIS measurements is tested by means of Kramer-Kronig analyses with the aid of ec-idea software. The DRT data is obtained by using calculate from the impedance data with open-source MATLAB script-based software (DRT Tools).</div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> illustrates the concise construction of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles embedded in an N-doped carbon skeleton using a multiscale structural engineering strategy. In the typical preparation process, antimony trichloride is utilized as Sb sources for the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@NPC, while <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span> citrate and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/melamine" title="Learn more about melamine from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">melamine</a> are used as carbon and nitrogen sources. Subsequently, the solid powder is subjected to a one-step </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> and partial reduction process, followed by calcining, resulting in the formation of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles embedded in the N-doped porous carbon skeleton. Finally, through removing the spontaneously formed K<sub>2</sub>O templates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>) with distilled water to obtain the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a–f reveals the SEM images of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5, respectively. The unique 3D structure of the samples provides an efficient transmission path for electrons and Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. To further reveal the microstructure of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC, we utilize the TEM to analyze the relevant samples. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a–c demonstrate that the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles are embedded within the porous carbon skeleton structure. Different addition amounts of antimony trichloride impact the loading and dispersion degrees of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles in the carbon matrix. As demonstrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d–f, it can be concluded that excessive Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> nanoparticles will aggregate into large particles within the carbon skeleton after high-temperature <a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a>. Large particles generally cause significant mechanical stress and even severe volume expansion on electrode materials </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g–i further reveal the presence of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles cladded by porous carbon. The lattice fringes have an interplanar spacing of 0.321&nbsp;nm corresponding to the (2&nbsp;2&nbsp;2) crystal planes of Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, and 0.311&nbsp;nm corresponding to the (0&nbsp;1&nbsp;2) crystal planes of Sb <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a><span>. The element mapping results demonstrate that the sample contains Sb, C, O and N elements, which are homogeneously distributed in the composites. Moreover, the overlapping signals of N and C elements indicate that the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nitrogen-atom" title="Learn more about nitrogen atoms from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nitrogen atoms</a> have been evenly doped into the carbon skeleton.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1.jpg" height="349" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (267KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (267KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Synthesis process of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2.jpg" height="368" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (502KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (502KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Morphology characterizations of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> images of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (a, d), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (b, e), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (c, f).</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3.jpg" height="877" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Morphology characterizations of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (a, d), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (b, e), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 (c, f). Lattice fringes (g–i), and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> results (j) of the Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 composites.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a shows that the crystal structures of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 are analyzed by <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a>. The results demonstrate that all the peaks of each sample correspond to Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (JCPDS No. 05-0534) and Sb (JCPDS No. 35-0732) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a><span>. The surface area of the samples is further examined by measuring the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. All samples exhibited type IV isotherms with <a href="/topics/engineering/hysteresis-loop" title="Learn more about hysteresis loops from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hysteresis loops</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b). Meanwhile, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 exhibit similar adsorption properties at extremely-low relative pressures. It can be determined that <a href="/topics/engineering/micropore" title="Learn more about micropores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">micropores</a> coexist in the samples. According to the BET analysis, the surface areas of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are calculated to be 303.8, 379.6 and 232.2&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c shows that the pore sizes of these three samples range from 1&nbsp;nm to 40&nbsp;nm. There is almost no microporous structure in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@PC-1.0, which due to melamine is not added during the synthesis process. Therefore, it can be concluded that the formation of micropores is related to the gas template generated during the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a> process, while </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> originate more from the K</span><sub>2</sub>O solid template. The Raman spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d displays the typical peaks at 1350 and 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, which are attribute to the D-band (disordered structure) and G-band (sp<sup>2</sup><span> carbon structure). The increase in the intensity of the D peak can be attributed to the successful doping of nitrogen and the creation of lattice defects, which lead to the disorder of the <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a><span>. Generally, <a href="/topics/engineering/structural-defect" title="Learn more about structural defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural defects</a> in carbon materials can be revealed by the intensity ratio </span></span><em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em>. Obviously, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 displays a higher <em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em> ratio of 1.16 than those of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (1.06), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (0.92) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>@C-1.0 (0.77). Abundant <a href="/topics/engineering/defect-structure" title="Learn more about defect structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect structures</a> are beneficial for </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> storage </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. In addition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to analyze the chemical composition of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. The elemental mapping results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e) are confirmed by the presence of C, Sb, O and N elements in the full spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>f, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/deconvolution" title="Learn more about deconvolution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deconvolution</a> of the high-resolution C 1s spectrum indicates four subpeaks, which correspond to C</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C (284.8&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">O (285.5&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (286.5&nbsp;eV) and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O (288.4&nbsp;eV) bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. The Sb 3d XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g) of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 shows six characteristic peaks: metallic Sb at 530.1&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>5/2</sub>) and 539.6&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>3/2</sub>), Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> at 530.9&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>5/2</sub>) and 540.4&nbsp;eV (Sb 3d<sub>3/2</sub>), and O (1s) at 532.3&nbsp;eV and 533.5&nbsp;eV <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>h indicates the N 1s high-resolution XPS spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. Obviously, the spectrum exhibits three peaks at approximately 398.4&nbsp;eV, 400.3&nbsp;eV and 402.9&nbsp;eV, corresponding to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and graphitic N, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i, pyridinic N has lone pairs occupying sp<sup>2</sup><span> orbitals, while pyrrolic N has p-orbital lone pairs predominantly located at edges or <a href="/topics/engineering/defect-site" title="Learn more about defect sites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect sites</a> in the carbon skeleton plane. Both pyridinic N and pyrrolic N facilitate Na</span><sup>+</sup> absorption, contributing to an increase in surface capacitance capacity. Regrettably, graphitic N is unreactive in absorbing Na<sup>+</sup> due to the two unpaired electrons in its two p-orbitals. Based on <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S2 and S3</span></span></a>, it can be found that Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 also exhibit similar <a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental compositions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental compositions</a> and properties, which demonstrate the generalizability of this synthesize method. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>, the percentages of pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphite N in these samples are calculated based on N1s high-resolution XPS spectrum.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4.jpg" height="606" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (756KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (756KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites. (b) Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm. (c) pore-size distributions of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (d) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (e) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0, (f) C 1s, (g) Sb 3d and (h) N 1s spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. (i) Schematic structure of the binding conditions of N in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">The performance of Na<sup>+</sup> storage in the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites is evaluated by assembling 2032 type coin cells. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a exhibits the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0. During the first discharge process, a peak at 0.94&nbsp;V is observed due to the formation of SEI films and the generation of irreversible terms. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. The two cathodic peaks located at 0.43 and 0.51&nbsp;V are ascribed to the alloying processes of Sb to Na<sub>3</sub>Sb. The two anodic peaks located at 0.75&nbsp;V and 0.84&nbsp;V are corresponding to the process of dealloying <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>. Interestingly, the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 also show the same alloying/dealloying process (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b exhibits a detailed description of the alloying reaction mechanism during the CV process of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. The reaction process can be summarized by the following equation: Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;6Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;6e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;2Sb&nbsp;+&nbsp;3Na<sub>2</sub>O, Sb&nbsp;+&nbsp;xNa<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;xe<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;⇋&nbsp;Na<sub>x</sub>Sb (0&nbsp;≤&nbsp;x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;3). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c–e exhibits the galvanostatic current discharge/charge curves of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 at a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The initial reversible capacity and coulombic efficiency of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 are 969.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 55&nbsp;% for SIBs. The initial coulombic efficiency for Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are 46&nbsp;% and 52&nbsp;%, respectively. The loss of first-loop capacity is generally caused by the formation of SEI films on the surface of porous carbon materials and the irreversible phase formation.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5.jpg" height="780" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (856KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (856KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 0.1 mVs<sup>−1</sup>. (b) Mechanism diagram of alloying reaction in Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites. (c–e) Charge/discharge curves at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup> of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (f) <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites in their initial cycle. (g) In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> spectrum of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 2th cycle. (h) Rate performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at different current densities (i) cycling performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">Detailed reaction kinetics of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC in SIBs is explored using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) range from 100&nbsp;kHz to 0.01&nbsp;Hz. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>f exhibits the typical <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> for the anode of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC, which consisting of semicircles and diagonal lines. The semicircle represents the <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a>, while the diagonal line is related to the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>. The EIS equivalent circuit diagrams of fresh half cells is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>. Where R<sub>e</sub> is the ohmic impedance, R<sub>ct</sub> is the charge transfer impedance, Z<sub>w</sub> is the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion impedance and R<sub>SEI</sub> is the impedance of Na<sup>+</sup><span> across the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a>. The large surface area offers sufficient electrode/electrolyte interface for Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> uptake and facilitates fast charge transfer reactions. The <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/hierarchical-porous" title="Learn more about hierarchical porous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hierarchical porous</a> structure provides a fast transfer pathway and reduces the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> transfer distance, while the crosslinked carbon network provides a continuous path for <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a><span>. In addition, N-doping improves the electrochemical responsiveness and <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> of the Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g shows the in-situ impedance spectrum of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0. After two cycles, the smooth impedance variation and excellent recovery are attributed to the stability of the porous <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a>. Afterwards, the rate performances of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC are explored at different current densities. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h, it can be found that the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 achieves high charge capacities of 503.6, 430.4, 384.9, 340.3, 297.7 and 186.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. After continuous inrush of high current (5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>), the reversible capacity can be restored to 477.4&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> when the current density is back to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The high-rate capability of the material can be attributed to the integrated N-doped porous network structure embedded with Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles. To explore the stability of the N-doped porous network structure, the long cycling performance of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 are investigated at the current density of 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>i). After 1000 cycles, the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 remains a high capacity of 300.3&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 86.7&nbsp;%, which is superior to Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (219.5&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 77.8&nbsp;%) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (159.4&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention of 51.8&nbsp;%). To evaluate the practicality of our electrodes, we select the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 electrode with <a href="/topics/engineering/optimal-performance" title="Learn more about optimal performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">optimal performance</a> to assemble the full cell. The cathode electrode of the full cell is Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) electrode. The full cell delivers the initial charge/discharge capacities of 123.8/107.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C with a high ICE of 87.1&nbsp;% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>), and the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves show agreeable overlaps after the first cycle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>). The charge capacity of 98.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C can be obtained after 100 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 86.8&nbsp;%, demonstrating excellent cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080"><span>During the cycling process, the formation of SEI films not only affects the electron transfer resistance of the <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a>, but is also related to the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> transfer resistance. Therefore, to further investigate the evolution law of SEI films in the sodium <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a>, it is necessary to analyze the effect of SEI films generation on the electron transfer and Na</span><sup>+</sup> transport at the electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a shows that the processes that Na<sup>+</sup> undergoes in the composite include diffusion in the bulk phase, charge transfer reactions and transport processes across the SEI films. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b, the SEI film thickens gradually with the charge–discharge reaction. The corresponding Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-path" title="Learn more about diffusion path from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion path</a> is decreased in the bulk phase and the path across the SEI films is increased. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>c demonstrates the thickness of the SEI films after 2nd, 5th, 100th, 500th and 1000th cycles through <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM analysis</a>, which profoundly reveals the variation pattern of SEI films thickness.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6.jpg" height="758" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (764KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (764KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0065"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>(a) Schematic diagram of <a href="/topics/engineering/distributions-of-relaxation-time" title="Learn more about DRT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT</a> testing and its processes related to τ</span><sub>1</sub>, τ<sub>2</sub>, and τ<sub>3</sub>. (b) Schematic diagram of Na<sup>+</sup><span> pathway changes before and after <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> cycling. (c) TEM images (Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0) of SEI film thickness with different number of cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>a reveals the trend of impedance change at different number of cycles. As the number of cycles increases, the ohmic impedance does not change significantly. Due to electrode activation, the charge transfer impedance decreases first and then increases. The diffusion impedance decreases lead to an appropriate increase in the ion diffusion rate. Overall, the impedance shows an increasing trend. However, the impedance spectrum is difficult to distinguish the influence of the individual frequency components. Therefore, it is important to realize a detailed analysis of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/phase-interface" title="Learn more about phase interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phase interface</a> evolution process during Na</span><sup>+</sup> storage. Various kinetic processes with specific relaxation features can be clearly identified in time scales through DRT analysis <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0315" name="bb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. Extracting and analyzing time-scale information in cells will provide insights into the investigation of kinetic aspects such as Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> diffusion charge transfer, and interfacial evolution. In the <a href="/topics/engineering/relaxation-time-spectrum" title="Learn more about DRT spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT spectrum</a>, the x-axis is a time constant, representing the inherent characteristics of each </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-process" title="Learn more about electrochemical process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical process</a><span>, and the peak intensity is the impedance of the corresponding process. Therefore, various processes with different <a href="/topics/engineering/response-time" title="Learn more about response times from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">response times</a> can be separated and identified in the DRT spectrum, and the changes of each process can be tracked. In general, the response times corresponding to diffusion of Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> in the electrode material bulk phase, the charge transfer reaction and the transport of Na<sup>+</sup> across the SEI films are τ<sub>1</sub>&nbsp;&gt;&nbsp;10&nbsp;s, 0.01&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;τ<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;10&nbsp;s and 0.001&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;τ<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.01&nbsp;s, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0320" name="bb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a><span>. In this study, DRT analysis is performed on EISs with different number of cycles to distinguish the corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> processes at the characteristic frequencies. The selected EIS data is first validated at Kramers-Kronig to fulfill the requirements of DRT impedance analysis. As illustrated in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b–c, in the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0, the intensity of the τ<sub>1</sub> characteristic peaks gradually decrease as the number of cycles increases, which improves the wetting degree of the electrolyte to the electrode and the diffusion process becomes favorable. The τ<sub>2</sub><span> characteristic peaks show a significant decrease during the <a href="/topics/engineering/activation-process" title="Learn more about activation process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation process</a> and tend to flatten after activation. The intensity of the τ</span><sub>3</sub> characteristic peak initially decreases, and after the activation process, the peak intensity gradually increases and shifts to the right, indicating that the transport resistance of Na<sup>+</sup> in the SEI films increase gradually. Fig. d–f show the variation trend of τ<sub>1</sub>, τ<sub>2</sub> and τ<sub>3</sub> in detail, and more clearly reveal the basis of the electrochemical reaction process. The above results demonstrate the continuous generation of SEI films during the cycling process, which is consistent with the TEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c). Meanwhile, it reveals the changing rule between the phase boundaries inside the electrode during Na<sup>+</sup> storage process. The evolution of the electrochemical reactions during cycling is further tested through CV tests at the scan rate of 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, and the corresponding CV curves of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 electrodes at 2 and 1000 cycles are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>g-i. The reduction peak and <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a><span> peak undergo a process of increase first and then decrease, which is consistent with the trend of EIS and DRT. The positions of all peaks remain almost constant, reflecting the stability of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/materials-structure" title="Learn more about material structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material structure</a>. The Sb/Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 also exhibit similar patterns of tendency in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S8 and S9</span></span></a>. Meanwhile, to further verify the changes inside the cell, the structure of the working electrodes before and after 1000 cycles of inspection are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>a–f. The Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 electrodes exhibit volume expansions of 31.1&nbsp;%, 32.7&nbsp;% and 40.3&nbsp;%, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>a–c illustrate that Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 exhibit fewer cracks on the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-surface" title="Learn more about electrode surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode surface</a> after cycling, while Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.5 shows an increased number of cracks. It is shown that the porous carbon structure synthesized by this method possess excellent stability and is suitable to be used as <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> for Na</span><sup>+</sup> batteries.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7.jpg" height="625" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (657KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (657KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0070"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><span>(a–c) <a href="/topics/engineering/distributions-of-relaxation-time" title="Learn more about DRT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DRT</a> analysis results obtained from </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 composites. (d–f) τ1, τ2, and τ3 peak intensity variation trend. (g-i) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 at 1.0 mVs<sup>-1</sup>at different cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">To further reveal the excellent Na<sup>+</sup> storage kinetics and mechanism of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 electrodes, the CV measurements are performed at several scan rates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a–c). It is evident that as the scan rate increases, the existing depolarization peak expands to a higher potential range, indicating the dominance of capacitively behaving Na<sup>+</sup> storage processes. As we all know, there is a relationship between the measured peak current (<em>i</em>) and the scan rate (<em>v</em>) that follows the equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0005" name="be0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="e0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mtext></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.405ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3188.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mtext is="true">b</mtext></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mtext is="true">b</mtext></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where a and b are adjustable constants. When b is close to 0.5, indicating that the electrochemical reaction is controlled by diffusion process, while b approaches 1.0, representing the electrochemical reaction is surface capacitive-dominated. The b-value can be calculated by linearly fitting the log(<em>i</em>)–log(<em>v</em>) points. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>d–f, the b-values of two redox peaks for Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (calculated to be 0.75 and 0.77), Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 (calculated to be 0.80 and 0.83) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (calculated to be 0.74 and 0.76) demonstrate that three electrode capacities are from the capacitive process. Furthermore, the Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanism can be further verified by probing the current response to the applied scan rate, which can be described as equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mtext><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mtext><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="19.582ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 8431.2 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(512,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(875,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2054,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3110,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4093,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4800,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5801,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6783,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">v</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">v</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mtext is="true">k</mtext><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>in which k<sub>1</sub> and k<sub>2</sub> are constants, k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> represents the surface-driven pseudocapacitive contribution and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup> represents the ion diffusion-controlled process. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>g–i indicates the capacitive-controlled contribution ratios of the three electrodes at the scan rate of 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S8–S10</span></span></a> show the values of other scan rates). Calculated by integral fitting, Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0 exhibits a capacitive-controlled contribution of 73.9&nbsp;%, which is higher than those of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-0.5 (65.3&nbsp;%) and Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.5 (64.7&nbsp;%). The ratio of pseudocapacitive contribution increases with the scan rate (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>j–l), indicating that the storage capacity of Na<sup>+</sup> is dominated by a capacitive process. Therefore, it can be inferred that the high percentage of capacitance contribution is the reason for the superior rate capability of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC-1.0.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8.jpg" height="833" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (886KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (886KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724013274-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0075"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (a–c) CV curves of the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites at different scan rates. (d–f) log <em>i</em> versus log <em>v</em> plots at two redox peaks of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC composites. (g–i) The capacitive contribution to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about Sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium</a> storage at 1&nbsp;mV·s</span><sup>−1</sup>. (j–l) Contribution ratios of capacitance and diffusion at different scan rates for the Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NPC composites.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">In summary, we prepared composite materials of Sb/Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span> nanoparticles embedded in N-doped porous carbon using the gas–solid dual <a href="/topics/engineering/template-method" title="Learn more about template method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">template method</a><span>. Carbon encapsulation and the <a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structure</a> not only significantly limits the volume expansion during the alloying process, but also controls the diffusion of </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> during cycling, thereby improving the kinetics of alloying reactions. The synergistic combination of ex-situ TEM and DRT analysis significantly enhances the accuracy of kinetic interpretation in SIBs. This novel method proposes an effective approach to mitigate volume expansion in Sb-based electrodes. The Sb/Sb</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>@NPC-1.0 demonstrates excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a>, achieving 340.3 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 1A g<sup>−1</sup> and maintaining 86.7&nbsp;% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. These findings provide a promising strategy for the practical application of SIBs, particularly in the development of high-performance and long-lasting anode materials.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><strong>Guang Ma:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Investigation. <strong>Chong Xu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision. <strong>Dongyuan Zhang:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Sai Che:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Ye Wang:</strong> Supervision, Investigation. <strong>Jiahao Yang:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. <strong>Kaiyi Chen:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Validation. <strong>Yang Sun:</strong> Supervision, Investigation. <strong>Shuang Liu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Junjie Fu:</strong> Validation, Investigation. <strong>Zizheng Zhou:</strong> Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Yiming Qu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Changsheng Ding:</strong> Writing – review &amp;
